questions.prompt: Consider the three breadboards above, using the same battery voltage and light bulbs. Which statement best explains the different bulb brightness?

options.option: More bulbs in series means less current, and so, less light output.
options.feedback: Bravo! The total resistance increases with additional bulbs. Ohmâ€™s Law tells us that the battery will then deliver less current. And that means less power output by each bulb.

options.option: More bulbs in series means less voltage from the battery, and so, less light output.
options.feedback: No, the battery will always deliver about the same voltage. Try again.

options.option: More bulbs in series means less total resistance, and so, less light output.
options.feedback: No, actually resistors in   series will add their values. The total resistance when connected in series is greater. How will that make the circuit behave? Try again.

options.option: More bulbs in series quickly shorts out the battery, and so, soon the bulbs quit emitting light.
options.feedback: No, more resistors in series will reduce the current and so the battery will last longer.  Try again.

questions.prompt: If you were to lift one of the leads from the right-hand bulb in Case 2, what will happen?

options.option: The current will stop, and so all the bulbs would go out.
options.feedback:
That's right! The battery current must flow through all the parts of a series circuit, so breaking the circuit means zero current, and so no light.

You can advance to the next level.

options.option: All the voltage will be across the other bulb, so it will get brighter and the right-hand bulb will go out.
options.feedback: No, when one lead is lifted, the current stops, and so none of the bulbs will light up. Try again.

options.option: All the voltage will be across the right-hand bulb, so it will get brighter and the left-hand bulb will go out.
options.feedback: No, when one lead is lifted, the current stops, and so none of the bulbs will light up. Try again.

options.option: All the current will flow through the left-hand bulb, so it will get brighter.
options.feedback: No, when one lead is lifted, the current stops, and so none of the bulbs will light up.

options.option: Since the total resistance is less, the bulbs will get brighter.
options.feedback: No, when one lead is lifted, the current stops, and so none of the bulbs will light up. The total resistance has nothing to do with this. Try again.
